pairs.stoic_text:
A rash seaman never considers what wind blows, or what course he
steers, but runs at a venture, as if he would brave the rocks and the
eddies; whereas he that is careful and considerate, informs himself
beforehand where the danger lies, and what weather it is like to be:
he consults his compass, and keeps aloof from those places that are
infamous for wrecks and miscarriages; so does a wise man in the common
business of life; he keeps out of the way from those that may do him
hurt: but it is a point of prudence not to let them take notice that
he does it on purpose; for that which a man shuns he tacitly condemns.
Let him have a care also of _listeners_, _newsmongers_, and _meddlers_
in other people’s matters; for their discourse is commonly of such
things as are never profitable, and most commonly dangerous either to
be spoken or heard.
pairs.neutral_text:
A reckless sailor doesn't pay attention to wind conditions or navigation, but sails randomly as if he wants to hit rocks and dangerous currents. A careful sailor, however, learns ahead of time where the hazards are and what weather to expect. He checks his compass and stays away from areas known for shipwrecks and accidents.

A smart person acts the same way in everyday life. He avoids people who might harm him, but he's careful not to make it obvious that he's avoiding them on purpose, because when someone avoids something, it implies criticism.

He should also be cautious around people who eavesdrop, spread rumors, and interfere in others' business. These people usually talk about things that are useless and often dangerous to either say or hear.

pairs.stoic_text:
Shall any man see the glory and order of the universe; so many
scattered parts and qualities wrought into one mass; such a medley of
things, which are yet distinguished: the world enlightened, and the
disorders of it so wonderfully regulated; and shall he not consider
the Author and Disposer of all this; and whither we ourselves shall
go, when our souls shall be delivered from the slavery of our flesh?
The whole creation we see conforms to the dictates of Providence, and
follows God both as a governor and as a guide. A great, a good, and
a right mind, is a kind of divinity lodged in flesh, and may be the
blessing of a slave as well as of a prince; it came from heaven, and to
heaven it must return; and it is a kind of heavenly felicity, which a
pure and virtuous mind enjoys, in some degree, even upon earth: whereas
temples of honor are but empty names, which, probably, owe their
beginning either to ambition or to violence.
pairs.neutral_text:
When someone observes the organized structure of the universe - how many separate parts and qualities come together to form one whole, how different things exist together while remaining distinct, how the world functions and its problems get resolved in remarkable ways - shouldn't they think about who created and manages all this? They should also consider what happens to us when our souls are freed from our physical bodies after death.

Everything we see in creation follows the rules of divine providence and obeys God as both ruler and leader. A great, good, and moral mind is like having a piece of God within human flesh. This kind of mind can belong to a slave just as much as to a prince. It comes from heaven and will return to heaven. A pure and virtuous mind experiences a type of heavenly happiness even while living on earth. In contrast, prestigious titles and honors are meaningless - they probably started because of people's ambition or use of force.

pairs.stoic_text:
Græcinus Julius (whom Caligula put to death out of a pure malice to his
virtue) had a considerable sum of money sent him from Fabius Persicus
(a man of great and infamous example) as a contribution towards the
expense of plays and other public entertainments; but Julius would
not receive it; and some of his friends that had an eye more upon the
present than the presenter, asked him, with some freedom, what he meant
by refusing it? “Why,” says he, “do you think that I will take money
where I would not take so much as a glass of wine?” After this Rebilus
(a man of the same stamp) sent him a greater sum upon the same score.
“You must excuse me,” says he to the messenger, “for I would not take
any thing of Persicus neither.”
pairs.neutral_text: Græcinus Julius (who was killed by Caligula because Caligula hated his good character) received an offer of a large amount of money from Fabius Persicus (a man known for his bad reputation). The money was meant to help pay for plays and other public events. Julius refused to accept it. Some of his friends, who cared more about the money than who was offering it, asked him directly why he was turning it down. He replied, "Do you think I would take money from someone I wouldn't even have a drink with?" Later, Rebilus (another man with a bad reputation) offered him an even larger sum for the same purpose. Julius told the messenger, "I can't accept this either, since I wouldn't take anything from Persicus."

pairs.stoic_text:
How terrible is death to one man, which to another appears the greatest
providence in nature, even toward all ages and conditions! It is the
wish of some, the relief of many, and the end of all. It sets the slave
at liberty, carries the banished man home, and places all mortals upon
the same level: insomuch, that life itself were a punishment without
it. When I see tyrants, tortures, violences, the prospect of death is a
consolation to me, and the only remedy against the injuries of life.
pairs.neutral_text: People have very different reactions to death. Some people find it terrifying, while others see it as beneficial and natural for everyone regardless of age or social status. Some people want to die, many find it provides relief from suffering, and it eventually happens to everyone. Death frees slaves, allows exiles to return home, and makes all people equal. Without death, life would be unbearable. When I observe dictators, torture, and violence, the possibility of death comforts me because it's the only way to escape life's harm.

pairs.stoic_text:
The humanity and excellence of this virtue is confessed at all hands,
as well by the men of _pleasure_, and those that think every man was
made for himself, as by the Stoics, that make “man a sociable creature,
and born for the common good of mankind:” for it is of all dispositions
the most _peaceable_ and _quiet_. But before we enter any farther upon
the discourse, it should be first known what _clemency_ is, that we may
distinguish it from _pity_; which is a _weakness_, though many times
mistaken for a _virtue_: and the next thing will be, to bring the mind
to the _habit_ and _exercise_ of it.
pairs.neutral_text:
Everyone agrees that this virtue is good and human, including people who live for pleasure and think everyone should look out for themselves, as well as Stoics who believe humans are naturally social and born to help all of humanity. This virtue creates the most peaceful and calm disposition of all.

Before we discuss this topic further, we need to first define what clemency is so we can tell it apart from pity. Pity is actually a weakness, even though people often mistake it for a virtue. After that, we will explain how to develop clemency as a habit and put it into practice.

pairs.stoic_text:
This is one of those subtleties, which, though hardly worth a man’s
while, yet it is not labor absolutely lost neither. There is more of
trick and artifice in it than solidity; and yet there is matter of
diversion too; enough perhaps to pass away a winter’s evening, and keep
a man waking that is heavy-headed.
pairs.neutral_text: This topic is a minor subtlety that probably isn't worth spending much time on, but studying it isn't completely pointless either. It relies more on clever techniques than on substantial content, but it can still be entertaining - possibly enough to fill an evening in winter and help someone stay alert when they're feeling drowsy.

pairs.stoic_text:
The principal causes of ingratitude are pride and self-conceit,
avarice, envy, etc. It is a familiar exclamation, “It is true he did
this or that for me, but it came so late, and it was so little, I had
even as good have been without it—if he had not given it to me, he must
have given it to somebody else—it was nothing out of his pocket.” Nay,
we are so ungrateful, that he that gives us all we have, if he leaves
any thing to himself, we reckon that he does us an injury.
pairs.neutral_text: The main reasons people are ungrateful are pride, self-importance, greed, and jealousy. People commonly say things like "Yes, he helped me, but it was too late and wasn't enough. I could have managed without it. If he hadn't given it to me, he would have given it to someone else anyway. It didn't cost him anything." People are so ungrateful that even when someone gives them almost everything they have, they feel wronged if that person keeps anything for themselves.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is a common thing to screw up justice to the pitch of an injury. A
man may be _over-righteous_; and why not _over-grateful_ too? There is
a mischievous excess, that borders so close upon ingratitude, that it
is no easy matter to distinguish the one from the other: but, in regard
that there is good-will in the bottom of it, (however distempered, for
it is effectually but kindness out of the wits,) we shall discourse it
under the title of _Gratitude mistaken_.
pairs.neutral_text: People sometimes take justice too far and turn it into harm. A person can be excessively righteous, so why not excessively grateful as well? There is a harmful kind of excess gratitude that is so similar to ingratitude that it's difficult to tell them apart. However, since this excess comes from good intentions at its core (even though it's misguided - it's essentially kindness that has gone wrong), we will discuss it as "misunderstood gratitude."

pairs.stoic_text:
Provided that we look to our consciences, no matter for opinion: let
me deserve well, though I hear ill. The common people take stomach and
audacity for the marks of magnanimity and honor; and if a man be soft
and modest, they look upon him as an easy fop; but when they come once
to observe the dignity of his mind in the equality and firmness of his
actions; and that his external quiet is founded upon an internal peace,
the very same people who have him in esteem and admiration; for there
is no man but approves of virtue, though but few pursue it; we see
where it is, but we dare not venture to come at it: and the reason is,
we overvalue that which we must quit to obtain it.
pairs.neutral_text:
As long as we follow our moral principles, it doesn't matter what others think. I want to act properly even if people criticize me. Most people mistake aggression and boldness for greatness and honor. When someone is gentle and humble, they see that person as weak or foolish. But once people notice the strength of character shown through consistent and steady behavior, and realize that outward calmness comes from inner peace, those same people will respect and admire that person.

Everyone approves of virtue, but few people actually practice it. We can recognize virtue when we see it, but we're afraid to pursue it ourselves. The reason is that we place too much value on the things we would have to give up to become virtuous.

pairs.stoic_text:
I came one night weary home, and threw myself upon the bed with this
consideration about me: “There is nothing ill that is well taken.” My
baker tells me he has no bread; but, says he, I may get some of your
tenants, though I fear it is not good. No matter, said I, for I will
stay until it be better—that is to say until my stomach will be glad
of worse. It is discretion sometimes to practice temperance and wont
ourselves to a little, for there are many difficulties both of time and
place that may force us upon it.
pairs.neutral_text: I came home tired one evening and lay down on my bed thinking about this idea: "Nothing bad is truly bad if you accept it well." My baker told me he had no bread, but he said I might be able to get some from my tenants, though he wasn't sure about the quality. I told him it didn't matter because I would wait until conditions improved—meaning until I became hungry enough to be happy with lower-quality food. It's sometimes wise to practice self-control and get used to having less, because various circumstances related to timing and location may force us to do without.

pairs.stoic_text:
Some magistrates are made for money, and those commonly are bribed with
money. We are all turned merchants, and look not into the quality of
things, but into the price of them; for reward we are pious, and for
reward again we are impious. We are honest so long as we may thrive
upon it; but if the devil himself gives better wages, we change our
party. Our parents have trained us up into an admiration of gold and
silver, and the love of it is grown up with us to that degree that
when we would show our gratitude to Heaven, we make presents of those
metals. This it is that makes poverty look like a curse and a reproach;
and the poets help it forward; the chariot of the sun must be all of
gold; the best of times must be the Golden Age, and thus they turn the
greatest misery of mankind into the greatest blessings.
pairs.neutral_text: Some judges become judges to make money, and they are usually the ones who accept bribes. We have all become focused on commerce and only care about how much things cost rather than their actual value. We act religious when it benefits us financially, and we abandon our beliefs when it pays better. We stay honest only as long as it helps us prosper, but we will switch sides if someone else offers us more money. Our parents taught us to value gold and silver above all else, and this obsession has become so strong that we even offer these metals as gifts to God. This mindset makes people view poverty as shameful and disgraceful. Poets make this worse by always associating gold with good things - they describe the sun's chariot as golden, call the best historical period the Golden Age, and generally present what actually causes human suffering as something wonderful.

pairs.stoic_text:
And again, Seneca says very well in his Morals, “They worship the
images of the God,” says he, “kneel to them, and adore them, they are
hardly ever from them, either plying them with offerings or sacrifices,
and yet, after all this reverence to the image, they have no regard at
all to the workman that made it.”
pairs.neutral_text: Seneca makes a good point in his work on ethics. He observes that people worship statues of gods, bow down to them, and pray to them. They spend a lot of time with these statues, giving them gifts and performing sacrifices. However, despite showing so much respect to these images, they completely ignore the craftsman who actually made the statues.

pairs.stoic_text:
If the professors of virtue be as the world calls them, avaricious,
libidinous, ambitious—what are they then that have a detestation for
the very name of it: but malicious natures do not want wit to abuse
honester men than themselves. It is the practice of the multitude to
bark at eminent men as little dogs do at strangers; for they look upon
other men’s virtues as the upbraiding of their own wickedness. We
should do well to commend those that are good, if not, let us pass them
over; but, however, let us spare ourselves: for beside the blaspheming
of virtue, our rage is to no purpose. But to return now to my text.
pairs.neutral_text: If teachers of morality are greedy, lustful, and power-hungry as people say they are, then what does that make those who hate the very idea of virtue? Evil people are clever enough to attack those who are more honest than they are. Most people criticize distinguished individuals the way small dogs bark at strangers. They see other people's good qualities as reminders of their own bad behavior. We should praise good people when we can, or at least ignore them if we can't. Either way, we should control ourselves, because besides insulting virtue, our anger serves no purpose. But let me get back to my main point.

pairs.stoic_text:
In all these cases the mind rather suffers than acts, and therefore it
is not an affection _to be moved_, but _to give way_ to that motion,
and to follow willingly what was started by chance—these are not
affections, but impulses of the body. The bravest man in the world may
look pale when he puts on his armor, his knees knock, and his heart
work before the battle is joined: but these are only _motions_; whereas
_anger_ is an _excursion_, and proposes revenge or punishment, which
cannot be without the mind. As fear flies, so anger assaults; and it is
not possible to resolve, either upon violence or caution, without the
concurrence of the will.
pairs.neutral_text:
In all these situations, the mind is passive rather than active. Therefore, being moved by something is not an emotion - instead, emotions involve giving in to that movement and willingly following what began by accident. These are not emotions but physical responses from the body.

Even the bravest person might turn pale when putting on armor, have shaking knees, and feel their heart racing before a battle begins. However, these are just physical reactions. Anger, on the other hand, is an active response that seeks revenge or punishment, and this requires mental involvement. Fear causes people to run away, while anger makes them attack. It's impossible to decide on either violence or caution without the will being involved.

pairs.stoic_text:
Felicity is an unquiet thing; it torments itself, and puzzles the
brain. It makes some people ambitious, others luxurious; it puffs up
some, and softens others; only (as it is with wine) some heads bear
it better than others; but it dissolves all. Greatness stands upon a
precipice: and if prosperity carries a man never so little beyond his
poise, it overbears and dashes him to pieces. It is a rare thing for
a man in a great fortune to lay down his happiness gently; it being a
common fate for a man to sink under the weight of those felicities that
raise him. How many of the nobility did Marius bring down to herdsmen
and other mean offices! Nay, in the very moment of our despising
servants, we may be made so ourselves.
pairs.neutral_text:
Happiness causes restlessness and worry. It creates problems and confuses people's thinking. It makes some people seek power while others pursue luxury. Some people become arrogant from happiness, while others become weak. People react to happiness differently, similar to how people have different tolerances for alcohol, but happiness ultimately affects everyone negatively.

People in positions of power are in unstable situations. When success causes someone to lose their balance even slightly, it destroys them completely. It is unusual for a wealthy person to give up their good fortune peacefully. Most people are crushed by the same success that initially elevated them.

Marius forced many nobles to work as shepherds and other low-status jobs. Even when we look down on servants, we could quickly become servants ourselves.

pairs.stoic_text:
What is it that we plow the seas for; or arm ourselves against men and
beasts? To what end do we toil, and labor, and pile bags upon bags? We
may enlarge our fortunes, but we cannot our bodies; so that it does
but spill and run over, whatsoever we take more than we can hold. Our
forefathers (by the force of whose virtues we are now supported in our
vices) lived every jot as well as we, when they provided and dressed
their own meat with their own hands; lodged upon the ground, and were
not as yet come to the vanity of gold and gems; when they swore by
their earthen gods, and kept their oath, though they died for it.
pairs.neutral_text: Why do we travel across oceans for trade, or fight against people and animals? Why do we work so hard and accumulate wealth? We can increase our money, but we cannot make our bodies bigger to hold more. Any excess just goes to waste since we can only use what we need. Our ancestors, whose good qualities now allow us to live in luxury and vice, lived just as well as we do. They hunted and cooked their own food, slept on the ground, and had not yet become obsessed with gold and jewels. They made promises to their simple gods and kept those promises even when it meant death.

pairs.stoic_text:
A good and a wise man is not to be an _enemy_ of wicked men, but a
_reprover_ of them; and he is to look upon all the drunkards, the
lustful, the thankless, covetous, and ambitious, that he meets with,
not otherwise than as a physician looks upon his patients; for he that
will be angry with _any man_ must be displeased with _all_; which were
as ridiculous as to quarrel with a body for stumbling in the dark; with
one that is deaf, for not doing as you bid him; or with a school-boy
for loving his play better than his book. Democritus _laughed_, and
Heraclitus _wept_, at the folly and wickedness of the world, but we
never read of any _angry philosopher_.
pairs.neutral_text: A good and wise person should not be an enemy of bad people, but should correct them instead. When he encounters people who are drunk, lustful, ungrateful, greedy, or power-hungry, he should view them the same way a doctor views sick patients. If someone gets angry at one person for their flaws, they would have to be angry at everyone, since everyone has flaws. This would be as pointless as getting mad at someone for tripping in the dark, being upset with a deaf person for not following spoken instructions, or being angry at a child for preferring to play rather than study. The philosopher Democritus found human foolishness and wickedness amusing, while Heraclitus found it sad, but no philosopher in history was known for being angry about it.

pairs.stoic_text:
Can any man read the death of Pompey, and not be touched with an
indignation? The sound of a trumpet rouses the spirits and provokes
courage. It makes a man sad to see the shipwreck even of an enemy; and
we are much surprised by fear in other cases—all these motions are not
so much affections as preludes to them. The clashing of arms or the
beating of a drum excites a war-horse: nay, a song from Xenophantes
would make Alexander take his sword in his hand.
pairs.neutral_text: Reading about Pompey's death makes people feel angry. Hearing a trumpet makes people feel energetic and brave. Even seeing an enemy's ship sink makes people feel sad, and we often feel afraid when we see others in danger. These emotional reactions are not full emotions themselves, but rather the beginnings of emotions. The sound of weapons clashing or drums beating makes war horses excited. Similarly, when Xenophantes played music, it would cause Alexander to grab his sword.

pairs.stoic_text:
It was a severe instance, that of Piso too. A soldier that had leave
to go abroad with his comrade, came back to the camp at his time,
but without his companion. Piso condemned him to die, as if he had
killed him, and appoints a centurion to see the execution. Just as the
headsman was ready to do his office, the other soldier appeared, to the
great joy of the whole field, and the centurion bade the executioner
hold his hand. Hereupon Piso, in a rage, mounts the _tribunal_, and
sentences all three to death: the one because he was _condemned_,
the _other_ because it was for _his sake_ that his fellow-soldier
was _condemned_, the _centurion_ for not obeying the _order_ of his
_superior_. An ingenious piece of inhumanity, to contrive how to make
three criminals, where effectively there were none.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same passage in plain language:

General Piso provided another harsh example of injustice. A soldier received permission to leave camp with a fellow soldier. He returned on time but came back alone. Piso assumed he had murdered his companion and sentenced him to death. He ordered a centurion to oversee the execution. Just as the executioner was about to kill the soldier, the missing companion returned alive. Everyone in the camp was relieved, and the centurion told the executioner to stop.

However, Piso became angry. He went to his judgment seat and sentenced all three men to death: the first soldier because he had already been condemned, the second soldier because his disappearance had caused his companion's death sentence, and the centurion because he had disobeyed Piso's execution order. This was a cruel and illogical decision that turned three innocent people into criminals when no actual crime had been committed.

pairs.stoic_text:
Of all felicities, the most charming is that of a _firm_ and _gentle
friendship_. It sweetens all our cares, dispels our sorrows, and
counsels us in all extremities. Nay, if there were no other comfort in
it than the bare exercise of so generous a virtue, even for that single
reason, a man would not be without it. Beside, that it is a sovereign
antidote against all calamities, even against the fear of death itself.
pairs.neutral_text: Of all types of happiness, the most appealing is having a strong and kind friendship. It makes all our worries easier to bear, eliminates our sadness, and gives us advice during difficult times. Even if friendship had no other benefit than simply practicing such a valuable quality, that reason alone would make it worthwhile. Additionally, it serves as the best protection against all disasters, including the fear of dying.

pairs.stoic_text:
Next to the choice of the _person_ follows that of the _matter_;
wherein a regard must be had to time, place, proportion, quality;
and to the very nicks of opportunity and humor. One man values his
peace above his honor, another his honor above his safety; and not
a few there are that (provided they may save their bodies) never
care what becomes of their souls. So that good offices depend much
upon construction. Some take themselves to be obliged, when they are
not; others will not believe it, when they are; and some again take
obligations and injuries, the one for the other.
pairs.neutral_text: After choosing the person, you must choose the subject matter. You need to consider timing, location, appropriateness, and quality. You must also pay attention to the right opportunities and people's moods. Different people have different priorities: some value peace more than honor, others value honor more than safety, and some only care about physical survival and ignore moral consequences. Therefore, good deeds are often interpreted differently by different people. Some people feel obligated when they actually aren't, others refuse to acknowledge real obligations, and some people confuse favors with insults.

pairs.stoic_text:
We are here to encounter the most outrageous, brutal, dangerous, and
intractable of all passions; the most loathsome and unmannerly; nay,
the most ridiculous too; and the subduing of this monster will do a
great deal toward the establishment of human peace. It is the method of
_physicians_ to begin with a description of the disease, before they
meddle with the cure: and I know not why this may not do as well in the
distempers of the mind as in those of the body.
pairs.neutral_text: We are going to discuss one of the strongest and most harmful human emotions. This emotion is also disgusting, rude, and often ridiculous. Learning to control this emotion would greatly help create peace between people. Doctors usually describe a disease before they try to treat it. This same approach should work for mental problems just as well as it works for physical illnesses.

pairs.stoic_text:
He that has lived at sea in a storm, let him retire and die in the
haven; but let his retreat be without ostentation, and wherein he may
enjoy himself with a good conscience, without the want, the fear, the
hatred, or the desire, of anything, not out of malevolent detestation
of mankind, but for satisfaction and repose. He that shuns both
business and men, either out of envy, or any other discontent, his
retreat is but to the life of a mole: nor does he live to himself, as
a wise man does, but to his bed, his belly, and his lusts. Many people
seem to retire out of a weariness of public affairs, and the trouble of
disappointments; and yet ambition finds them out even in that recess
into which fear and weariness had cast them; and so does luxury, pride,
and most of the distempers of a public life.
pairs.neutral_text:
Someone who has experienced difficult times in public life should retire quietly and peacefully. Their retirement should be modest and allow them to live with a clear conscience, free from need, fear, hatred, or wanting things they don't have. This withdrawal should not be motivated by hatred of other people, but by a desire for personal satisfaction and rest.

However, if someone avoids work and other people because of jealousy or other negative feelings, their retirement becomes like living underground - isolated and unproductive. Such a person doesn't truly live for themselves in a wise way, but only focuses on comfort, food, and physical desires.

Many people appear to retire because they are tired of public responsibilities and frustrated by failures. But even in their private retreat, they are still troubled by the same problems that drove them away: ambition, luxury, pride, and other issues that plagued their public life continue to follow them.

pairs.stoic_text:
Assiduity of obligation strikes upon the conscience as well as the
memory, and pursues an ungrateful man till he becomes grateful: if one
good office will not do it, try a second, and then a third. No man can
be so thankless, but either shame, occasion, or example, will, at some
time or other, prevail upon him. The very beasts themselves, even lions
and tigers, are gained by good usage: beside, that one obligation does
naturally draw on another; and a man would not willingly leave his own
work imperfect. “I have helped him thus far, and I will even go through
with it now.” So that, over and above the delight and the virtue of
obliging, one good turn is a shouting-horn to another. This, of all
hints, is perhaps the most effectual, as well as the most generous.
pairs.neutral_text: Consistently doing good deeds for someone affects both their conscience and memory, and keeps pressure on an ungrateful person until they become grateful. If one good deed doesn't work, try a second one, then a third. No person is so ungrateful that shame, circumstances, or seeing others' examples won't eventually influence them. Even wild animals like lions and tigers respond to good treatment. Additionally, one favor naturally leads to another, and people don't like to leave their efforts unfinished. They think, "I've helped this person so far, so I might as well continue." Therefore, beyond the satisfaction and moral value of helping others, one good deed encourages another. This approach is probably both the most effective and the most generous of all strategies.

pairs.stoic_text:
As gratitude is a necessary and a glorious, so it is also an obvious, a
cheap, and an easy virtue; so obvious, that wheresoever there is a life
there is a place for it—so cheap that the covetous man may be grateful
without expense—and so easy that the sluggard may be so, likewise,
without labor. And yet it is not without its niceties too; for there
may be a time, a place or occasion wherein I ought not to return a
benefit; nay, wherein I may better disown it than deliver it.
pairs.neutral_text: Gratitude is necessary, valuable, and obvious. It's also inexpensive and requires little effort. Anyone who is alive can practice gratitude. Even greedy people can be grateful without spending money, and lazy people can be grateful without working hard. However, gratitude has some complexities. There are times, places, or situations where I should not repay a favor. Sometimes it might be better to reject a favor rather than return it.

pairs.stoic_text:
And every jot as ridiculous, though not so impious, was that of Cyrus;
who, in his design upon Babylon, found a river in his way that put a
stop to his march: the current was strong, and carried away one of the
horses that belonged to his own chariot: upon this he swore, that since
it had obstructed _his_ passage, it should never hinder any body’s
else; and presently set his whole army to work upon it, which diverted
it into a hundred and fourscore channels, and laid it dry. In this
ignoble and unprofitable employment he lost his time, and the soldiers
their courage, and gave his adversaries an opportunity of providing
themselves, while he was waging war with a river instead of an enemy.
pairs.neutral_text: Cyrus made an equally ridiculous mistake, though not as offensive to religion. When he was planning to attack Babylon, he came to a river that blocked his army's path. The river had a strong current and swept away one of the horses from his chariot. This made him angry, so he declared that since the river had blocked his way, he would make sure it never blocked anyone else's path again. He ordered his entire army to dig channels to divert the river. They dug 180 separate channels and completely dried up the original riverbed. This was a pointless task that wasted time and lowered his soldiers' morale. While Cyrus was focused on fighting the river instead of preparing for battle, his enemies had time to get ready for his attack.

pairs.stoic_text:
Nay, Providence itself is gracious to the wicked posterity of an
honorable race. The counsels of heaven are guided by wisdom, mercy, and
justice. Some men are made kings of their proper virtues, without any
respect to their predecessors: others for their ancestors’ sakes, whose
virtues, though neglected in their lives, come to be afterward rewarded
in their issues. And it is but equity, that our gratitude should extend
as far as the influence of their heroical actions and examples.
pairs.neutral_text: No, Providence actually shows kindness to the evil descendants of good families. God's decisions are based on wisdom, mercy, and justice. Some people become kings because of their own good qualities, regardless of who their ancestors were. Others become kings because of their ancestors' virtues, which may not have been properly recognized when those ancestors were alive, but are later rewarded through their descendants. It is only fair that our gratitude should reach as far as the positive effects of their heroic actions and examples.

pairs.stoic_text:
What can be happier than the condition both of mind and of fortune from
which we cannot fall—what can be a greater felicity than in a covetous,
designing age, for a roan to live safe among informers and thieves? It
puts a poor man into the very condition of Providence, that gives all,
without reserving anything to itself. How happy is he that owes nothing
but to himself, and only that which he can easily refuse or easily
pay! I do not reckon him poor that has but a little, but he is so that
covets more—it is a fair degree of plenty to have what is necessary.
Whether had a man better find satiety in want, or hunger in plenty? It
is not the augmenting of our fortunes, but the abating of our appetites
that makes us rich.
pairs.neutral_text:
A person who has little to lose experiences great peace of mind. When you own very little, you are safe from people who might try to cheat you or steal from you through false accusations. This is especially valuable in a time when many people are greedy and dishonest.

A poor person who gives freely is like God, who gives everything without keeping anything back. The happiest person is someone who only depends on himself and only owes what he can easily pay back or choose not to pay.

I don't consider someone poor just because they have little money. The truly poor person is the one who always wants more. Having enough to meet your basic needs is actually a good amount of wealth.

It's better to be satisfied with having little than to still feel hungry despite having plenty. We become wealthy not by getting more money and possessions, but by wanting less.

pairs.stoic_text:
The burning of Lyons may serve to show us that we are never safe, and
to arm us against all surprises. The terror of it must needs be great,
for the calamity is almost without example. If it had been fired by an
enemy, the flame would have left some further mischief to have been
done by the soldiers; but to be wholly consumed, we have not heard of
many earthquakes so pernicious: so many rarities to be destroyed in
one night; and in the depth of peace to suffer an outrage beyond the
extremity of war; who would believe it? but twelve hours betwixt so
fair a city and none at all! It was laid in ashes in less time than it
would require to tell the story.
pairs.neutral_text: The burning of Lyons demonstrates that we are never completely secure and should prepare for unexpected disasters. This event caused great fear because such complete destruction is extremely rare. Even if an enemy army had set the fire, soldiers would have left something behind. We have not seen many earthquakes cause this much damage. Many valuable and rare items were destroyed in a single night. During peacetime, the city suffered destruction worse than what typically happens during war, which is hard to believe. In just twelve hours, a beautiful city was completely gone. The city burned to ashes faster than it takes to describe what happened.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is an idle thing to pretend that we cannot govern our _anger_;
for some things that we do are much harder than others that we ought
to do; the wildest affections may be tamed by discipline, and there
is hardly anything which the mind will do but it may do. There needs
no more argument in this case than the instances of several persons,
both powerful and impatient, that have gotten the absolute mastery of
themselves in this point.
pairs.neutral_text: It's wrong to claim that we can't control our anger. We already do many things that are harder than the things we should do. Strong emotions can be controlled through practice, and the mind is capable of almost anything it sets out to do. We don't need more proof than the examples of people who were both influential and quick to anger, but who learned to completely control themselves in this area.
